Just following up here. It looks like disabling complexity regulation did
e=
liminate the dip in fitness (thanks Colin!). Seems odd that it would have
t=
his affect. Maybe it's a bug?

As far the elitism issue, it's some weird pr=
operty of having a lot of
individuals with 0 fitness. In the foraging domai=
n, some of the initial
networks get to a point where their velocity is 0 an=
d their velocity output
neuron is 0, meaning they're not moving and never w=
ill (because their
sensors will never change), resulting in a fitness of 0.=
 When this happens
to more than 80% of the individuals (sometimes it happen=
s to 100% of them),
then SharpNEAT only selects individuals with fitness > =
0 to survive. If
everyone is 0, then it looks like the champion is chosen r=
andomly or at
least arbitrarily? Either way, I can understand the design de=
cision, though
I'm not sure if I agree with it because it makes certain ext=
ensions
trickier if they depend on using the parents differently than the c=
hildren
in the evaluation. Setting fitness to a minimum of 1 fixes this so =
that it
chooses 18-21 individuals each generation when elitism is 0.2 and p=
opsize
is 100.

Wesley

On Sun, Dec 18, 2011 at 7:22 PM, Wesley Tansey <tan=
sey@...> wrote:

> Thanks Colin. I'm continuing to look into it and I'll=
 definitely try that.
>
> I've also noticed that the elitism is all over th=
e board. We have it set
> to 0.2 with a population of 100, so I'm expecting=
 it to be 20 individuals.
> However, it looks like it never gets to 20 in a=
 generation (usually around
> 15-18), and it can even go as low as 1 indivi=
dual at times. The elitism
> code in SN2 looks fairly sophisticated, so I w=
asn't sure if this was an
> intended default behavior or not. If it is, is =
there some way to reduce the
> variance so that we can always have 20 (mayb=
e +/- 2) survivors in the
> population?
>
> Wesley
>
>
> On Sun, Dec 18, 20=
11 at 7:16 PM, Colin Green <colin.green1@...>wrote:
>
>> **
>>
>>

been made

ning)

Just following up here. It looks like disabling complexity regulation did e=
liminate the dip in fitness (thanks Colin!). Seems odd that it would have t=
his affect. Maybe it's a bug?<div><br></div><div>As far the elitism iss=
ue, it's some weird property of having a lot of individuals with 0 fitn=
ess. In the foraging domain, some of the initial networks get to a point wh=
ere their velocity is 0 and their velocity output neuron is 0, meaning they=
're not moving and never will (because their sensors will never change)=
, resulting in a fitness of 0. When this happens to more than 80% of the in=
dividuals (sometimes it happens to 100% of them), then SharpNEAT only selec=
ts individuals with fitness > 0 to survive. If everyone is 0, then it lo=
oks like the champion is chosen randomly or at least arbitrarily? Either wa=
y, I can understand the design decision, though I'm not sure if I agree=
 with it because it makes certain extensions trickier if they depend on usi=
ng the parents differently than the children in the evaluation. Setting fit=
ness to a minimum of 1 fixes this so that it chooses 18-21 individuals each=
 generation when elitism is 0.2 and popsize is 100.</div>
<div><br></div><d=
iv>Wesley</div><div><br><div class=3D"gmail_quote">On Sun, Dec 18, 2011 at =
7:22 PM, Wesley Tansey <span dir=3D"ltr"><<a href=3D"mailto:tansey@...=
u">tansey@...</a>></span> wrote:<br><blockquote class=3D"gmail_quote"=
 style=3D"margin:0 0 0 .8ex;border-left:1px #ccc solid;padding-left:1ex">
T=
hanks Colin. I'm continuing to look into it and I'll definitely try=
 that.<div><br></div><div>I've also noticed that the elitism is all ove=
r the board. We have it set to 0.2 with a population of 100, so I'm exp=
ecting it to be 20 individuals. However, it looks like it never gets to 20 =
in a generation (usually around 15-18), and it can even go as low as 1 indi=
vidual at times. The elitism code in SN2 looks fairly sophisticated, so I w=
asn't sure if this was an intended default behavior or not. If it is, i=
s there some way to reduce the variance so that we can always have 20 (mayb=
e +/- 2) survivors in the population?</div>
